data.title: Podcast – Alison Fincher
data.meta_description: Posts about Podcast written by Alison Fincher
data.text:
Check out Episode 33 of the Read Japanese Literature podcast, The End of the World—Japanese Apocalypse, part 1.

In part one of this three part episode, we’re looking at apocalyptic and dystopian fiction as genres. Their origins in Western and Central Asia. Their evolution in Western Europe. And a history of English-language apocalyptic and dystopian storytelling that will provide us with context and a basis for comparison when we turn to Japanese stories in part two.

(Transcript of part 1.)

Check out Episode 34 of the Read Japanese Literature podcast, The End of the World—Japanese Apocalypse, part 2.

In part two of this three part episode, we’re looking at the apocalyptic and dystopian fiction of Japan.

We’ll begin with the evolution of the idea of “the end of the world” in Japan, especially after Japan started importing American and European science fiction. We’ll move on to Japanese apocalyptic stories, especially between 1945 and the 1970s and then during the 1970s and 1980s.

Part two mistakenly implies Jules Verne was an Anglo-American author. He was, obviously, French.

(Transcript of part 2.)

Check out Episode 35 of the Read Japanese Literature podcast, the End of the World—Japanese Apocalypse, part 3.

Part three examines the two most recent “eras” of Japanese apocalyptic fiction—1995-2011 and post 3/11/2011. It also takes a close look at the work of Yoko Tawada, especially her novel The Emissary, also published under the title The Last Children of Tokyo.

(Transcript of part 3.)

CW: brief mentions of historical and fictional violence and rape

This episode’s artwork is adapted from a photograph by Du Truong, “The Student of Gunkanjima”. Gunkanjima, also known as Hashima Island, is an abandoned island in Nagasaki Prefecture. Truong’s work is available under a Creative Commons license.

Other RJL Episodes of Interest:

Episode 15: Translating Japanese Women. Several times in this episode, I make reference to the limitations of what’s available in English and my gratitude for recently-translated fiction by women. “Translating Japanese Women” discusses why there is more Japanese fiction available in translation today. It also takes up the work of Sayaka Murata, discussed in part three.

Episode 22: Fukushima Fiction. Translator Ted Goossen correctly speculated that the events of 3/11 would anticipate a new kind of Japanese apocalyptic fiction.

Episode 24: SF! Japanese Science Fiction. Many works of apocalyptic fiction fall within the SF genre.
